prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Orcus/Vanth
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of the Orcus/Vanth system at 345 GHz. The proposal is for four observations of the system at four roughly equally spaced orbital phases of Vanth (orbital period ~9.7 days), at high resolution. This will allow us to detect the emission from the two bodies separately, and also to determine the precise position of Orcus through astrometry.

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note:
We request four observations to be executed roughly within a one week period, each separated by two days. The orbital period of Vanth around Orcus is ~9.5 days, so this will give us four roughly equally spaced observations. If that is not achievable, we can accept observations at other times, but they need to be at particular orbital phases of Vanth. In that case, once any initial observations are complete, we can provide the days on which further observations are acceptable. This is similar to requiring satellite observations at particular elongations. It will always be better to do the observations as close as possible in time, however, to limit systematics.
We are requesting 10 minutes more per session than the OT recommends to allow for extra astrometric calibrations.

HORIZONS Web-Interface This tool provides a web-based /limited/ interface to JPL's HORIZONS system </?horizons> which can be used to generate ephemerides for solar-system bodies. Full access to HORIZONS </?horizons> features is available via the primary telnet interface </?horizons#telnet>. HORIZONS system news </?horizons_news> shows recent changes and improvements. A web-interface tutorial </?horizons_tutorial> is available to assist new users.

-19.2682045 2015-Oct-24 00:00 m 10 08 51.4007 -08 52 07.488 48.6105922035783 -22.5446178 $$EOE ******************************************************************************* Column meaning:
TIME
Prior to 1962, times are UT1. Dates thereafter are UTC. Any 'b' symbol in the 1st-column denotes a B.C. date. First-column blank (" ") denotes an A.D. date. Calendar dates prior to 1582-Oct-15 are in the Julian calendar system. Later calendar dates are in the Gregorian system.
Time tags refer to the same instant throughout the universe, regardless of where the observer is located.
The dynamical Coordinate Time scale is used internally. It is equivalent to the current IAU definition of "TDB". Conversion between CT and the selected non-uniform UT output scale has not been determined for UTC times after the next July or January 1st. The last known leap-second is used over any future interval.
NOTE: "n.a." in output means quantity "not available" at the print-time.
SOLAR PRESENCE (OBSERVING SITE) Time tag is followed by a blank, then a solar-presence symbol:
'*' Daylight (refracted solar upper-limb on or above apparent horizon) 'C' Civil twilight/dawn 'N' Nautical twilight/dawn 'A' Astronomical twilight/dawn ' ' Night OR geocentric ephemeris
LUNAR PRESENCE (OBSERVING SITE) The solar-presence symbol is immediately followed by a lunar-presence symbol:
'm' Refracted upper-limb of Moon on or above apparent horizon ' ' Refracted upper-limb of Moon below apparent horizon OR geocentric ephemeris
R.A.___(ICRF/J2000.0)___DEC = J2000.0 astrometric right ascension and declination of target center. Adjusted for light-time. Units: HMS (HH MM SS.ffff) and DMS (DD MM SS.fff)
delta deldot = Range ("delta") and range-rate ("delta-dot") of target center with respect to the observer at the instant light seen by the observer at print-time would have left the target center (print-time minus down-leg light-time); the distance traveled by a light ray emanating from the center of the target and recorded by the observer at print-time. "deldot" is a projection of the velocity vector along this ray, the light-time-corrected line-of-sight from the coordinate center, and indicates relative motion. A positive "deldot" means the target center is moving away from the observer (coordinate center). A negative "deldot" means the target center is moving toward the observer. Units: AU and KM/S

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This project has two goals: determine the individual sizes and densities of Orcus and Vanth.
The size measurements will be accomplished through the well-established technique of radiometry. We will combine the observations at 345 GHz, which will separate the emission from Orcus and Vanth, with our unresolved cycle 1 data at 345 and 230 GHz and full Spitzer and Herschel coverage to model the thermal emission from both objects. Our simulations find that an SNR of 30 on the combined flux density of the two bodies should yield diameter uncertainties of about 5% for both bodies.
Our astrometric goal is to determine the position of Orcus as it deviates from its ephemeris position due to the gravitational tug of Vanth. The astrometric precision of an interferometer is half of the beam FWHM divided by the SNR (Reid et al. 1988). We require an astrometric precision of 2 masec per observation (see Fig 3). Given an intrinsic resolution of 130 masec (345 GHz at 1.5 km maximum spacing), this then in turn requires an SNR of 30. This thermal noise will dominate over systematics if we use calibrators of known absolute position better than 1 masec within 10 degrees of Orcus (Lestrade et al. 2007),. We will use one of J0959-0828 (1.3 degree separation), J1008-0933 (2.9 degrees), or J1011-0423 (3.7 degres) as the primary astrometric calibrator plus J0943-0819 and J1007-0207, both well-known millimeter calibrators also nearby, for the astrometric phase-referencing. During the entire period of ALMA cycle 2 Orcus only moves in the sky by about 3 degrees, so these calibrators should be good for the entire cycle.
Sensitivity: The required sensitivity is set by both the need to get the astrometric precision described above (SNR of 30 on Orcus), and the ability to determine the size of Vanth (minimum SNR of 3). In both cases, this yields a required sensitivity of ~50 uJy. Given calibration overheads indicated in the OT, and noting our comments on special calibrations below, this results in a total time per session of 65 minutes.
Imaging: These observations must be done in the largest configuration of ALMA (1.5 km maximum spacings), both in order to get the astrometric precision needed, and to separate Vanth from Orcus.
Correlator setup:These are all straightforward continuum observations at 345 GHz. We took the standard correlator setup for these observations from the OT.
Scheduling/Time constraints: We request four observations to be executed roughly within a one week period, each separated by two days. The orbital period of Vanth around Orcus is ~9.5 days, so this will give us four roughly equally spaced observations. If that is not achievable, we can accept observations at other times, but they need to be at particular orbital phases of Vanth. In that case, once any initial observations are complete, we can provide the days on which further observations are acceptable. This is similar to requiring satellite observations at particular elongations. It will always be better to do the observations as close as possible in time, however, to limit systematics.
"User-defined" Calibration: We do not require accurate flux density calibration, as we should already have a good flux density for the combined Orcus-Vanth system from our cycle 1 observations, and it is thus the relative flux density of the two that we are interested in. We will have to do special calibrations for the astrometry. We will set one of the calibrators from Table 1 as the primary phase calibrator, then two or three of the other calibrators (two of which will likely be J0943-0819 and J1007-0207) as ``target'' sources. One of us (Co-I Butler) has been involved in the commissioning of astrometric observations, so has experience with this kind of observation. Given the above two points, we require slightly more observing time than is given by the OT - by a few minutes.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The dwarf planets in the Kuiper belt provide one of the most compelling cases of the breakdown of the simple theory of pairwise accretion. The formation of these large rock-rich dwarf planets through coagulation of the population of small low density near rock-free objects appears difficult. Alternative accretion theories predict a wide variety of behaviors of the size-density relationship through the small body-large body transition. The Orcus-Vanth binary system is uniquely suited to determining the density behavior through this transition and pointing to the accretion history of the solar system. The new higher resolution capabilities of ALMA in Cycle 2 allow us, for the first time, to use resolved thermal radiometry to measure the individual component sizes and, the unique capability of highly accurate relative astrometry over moderate angles will let us determine the astrometric wobble of Orcus induced by Vanth to measure the individual component masses, yielding simultaneous densities of two of these transitional objects and a chance to determine how solid bodies in planetary systems form.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Geological and Planetary Sciences, California Institute of Technology
